{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3123056,"name":"","username":"Alex6940","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/47e85d/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-11T13:33:40.240Z","cooked":"

Since the Top ROW in 2023 is a bit far, something like a long arm or a pole is needed on the robot. I really worry that my robot may lean down on the ground because of such a stretching part. Are there any structural strategies that I can apply to avoid such a situation?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2023-01-11T13:33:40.240Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":249,"readers_count":248,"score":84.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":422410,"topic_slug":"how-to-prevent-my-robot-from-leaning-down","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52324,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-prevent-my-robot-from-leaning-down/422410/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3123058,"name":"","username":"Kevin_Leonard","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kevin_leonard/{size}/237299_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-11T13:35:52.555Z","cooked":"

Keep your robot weight as low (and perhaps back) as possible and your arm as light as possible.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2023-01-11T13:50:52.947Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":209,"readers_count":208,"score":101.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":422410,"topic_slug":"how-to-prevent-my-robot-from-leaning-down","display_username":"Nathan Shepherd","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25762,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2079 A -> 246 M -> 1153/1119 M"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-prevent-my-robot-from-leaning-down/422410/3","custom_user_title":"2079 A -> 246 M -> 1153/1119 M","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3123189,"name":"Stewart Riley","username":"Strategic","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/strategic/{size}/10157_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-11T16:07:00.619Z","cooked":"

There are two that come to mind: light weight and counterbalance. These are not mutually exclusive. As some have already pointed out, keeping the weight on the arm (of whatever type) low is a good way to make a robot less tippy. But you can also take a hint from cranes, which use counterweights opposite the arm extension to balance the crane and prevent tipping. This is also a viable design idea and one that, when combined with a low-as-possible arm weight can make your robot more stable.
